Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.

Price: One Piastre Tariff.
MONDAY, SEPTEMBER 3, 1906.

div.head: SLATIN PASHA ON NATIVE PEELING IN EGYPT.
div.p: Slatin Pasha, in the interview he gave to a Press representative in Vienna recently, made wine observations upon the prospects of the new Egyptian movement and the loyalty of the Egyptian Army which have a special interest as coming from the Inspector-General of the Anglo-Egyptian Sudan. From the detailed reports of the interview now available, it is clear that Slatin Pasha has full confidence in the trustworthiness of the Egyptian forces, both officers and men. The position held by British officers at the head of the Army does not affect its loyalty ;and he points out that it was never managed by Egyptians, but by Turks, and, in the words of the proverb, “Arabian and Turkish blood do not boil in the same pot.” Further, the Egyptian officer and soldier both know that it is to their inte- rest to protect the British officer. Their pay is punctual ; promotion, if slow, is fair and impartial ; and, Mahomedans though they are, they have no desire for a war between England and Turkey. Good discipline and the absence of desertion afford further testimony to the contentment of the soldiery.

With regard to the presence of fanaticism amongst the native population, about the time of the Akaba dispute, and the rumours of an upheaval, Slatin Pasha pointed to Sir F. Grey's statement in the House of Commons early in July that this fanaticism is found not only in Egypt, but is common along the whole North African coast ; and remarked that the symptoms of this fanatic nature are evident to every one who takes an interest in the welfare of the Egyptians and knows the pro- paganda which is being energetically spread by the leaders of the New Egyptian party. The results of this agitation are so much the greater because the Nationalists bring into the field not only their national sentiment but their religious tenets as well. The religious ques- tion is of the greatest importance, but it causes much perplexity to many a Mahomedan, who, formerly free from bias, has now to acknowledge that the British Government is a supreme blessing to them, and that the zealous and energetic work of Lord Cromer means a great deal for Egypt. The fellah especially perceives the great advantage of it, as he can cultivate his land quietly and peacefully, and can sell his harvest crop without being cheated by usurers, because he can obtain an advance from the State Bank at a small rate of inte- rest.

The Mahomedans of high social position see that the general welfare of the country is steadily increasing, that the value of the land and soil has of late years advanced very much in price by the systematic irrigation of dis- tricts which before lay uncultivated, that many millions in value are thereby gained, and that in spite of a decrease in taxation, the public revenue has yearly increased. Fur- ther, they also know that their religion is in no danger. Then a series of mosques is provided; Mahomedan schoolmasters are at work in the schools, and European masters are required for those provinces only where the natives are unable to teach.

While recognising the hatred of England in many high circles, which is natural in any land governed by foreigners, it is here deepen- ed by the question of religious separation, of which the New Egyptian party makes full use. The affair of Akaba offered the leaders of this party, which has political aims, an opportunity to rise against the foreigners, on the pretence that Islam was menaced. That the revolution- ary attitude of the Nationalists under these circumstances has caused a great upheaval the Tantah affair proved. Such an attack upon British officers might easily have occurred in earlier years. The punishment of the offenders may be censured as too severe by many Euro- pean newspapers — but quite wrongfully. Drastic measures alone provide the remedy in such cases, and only by sternness and fear are the hare-brained brought to reason. It would, however, be going too far to say that a serious danger is impending, and that there would soon be an outbreak of war. Nevertheless, to prevent such a danger in the future, it is necessary to show that England has not only the idea of holding Egypt, but also the force to maintain her hold there. The garrisons have been reinforced; and the Egyptians know that behind every Englishman stand hundreds of men ready to step into the breach.

Emphasising the fact that England up to now has not only respected the Mahomedan religion, but has honoured the leaders of Islam, Slatin Pasha said England would always respect the traditions and customs of the Egyptian peoples, but would also suppress with a strong arm any attempt to change the existing state of affairs—not for any selfish purpose, but to safeguard the welfare of everybody, be he Christian or Mahomedan. Slatin Pasha added that all who take an interest in Egypt, and who hope to see civilisation in Africa steadily increase, ought to concentrate their energies to maintain quiet and peace in Egypt. Simi- larly every Court circle in Europe, instead of finding fault with Great Britain, should con- sider that an outbreak of religious fanaticism on the part of the Mahomedans would not only endanger British sway in the East, but would injuriously affect every other State which pur- sues political and economical aims in the Orient, for a rising would bring misfortune upon all Europeans who dwell in Egypt, as well as ruin upon the Mahomedans themselves,

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Diphtheria at Damanhour
The Behera has issued stringent regulations in order to cope with the outbreak of diphtheria in the district of Damanhour.
Tramway Accident
At Shonbra, on Saturday evening, on the Rod el Farag line, a na'ive of Port Said in jumping off a tram fell on the path of another, and was cut in two.
U.S Petroleum.
Plus the 110,000 cases arriving by the Italian S.S. Regina Elena, the S.S. Vincenzo Bonanno and the S.S. Milton are expected here from New York with 112,094 cases.
Mex Casino.
A very jolly dance was that of Saturday night at Mex Casino, and certainly redounded to the credit of the committee of organisation. The hall was packed, and dancing kept up till a late hour.
Coiner Arrested.

A coiner of ten piastre pieces has been arrested at Boulac. He had given the money to a certain Soliman Ali and his wife to distribute, and on being questioned, they in- formed the police whence they had obtained the base coinage.
The Sirsina Affair.

The enquiry conducted by Mr. Kershaw is directed against the native population of Sirsina, end not against the Army of Occupa- tion, the postmortem examination having proved the death of the native to be due to a blow from a nabout
Avenue des Pyramides.

Since the assault on a European three weeks ago, a very strict watch is kept on the Avenue des Pyramides, which is patrolled by ghaffirs, shawishes, with bayonets fixed, and mounted police. This is very good, observes a Cairo contemporary, but the authorities would do much better if they threw some light on to the situation by a few gas lamps.
Towartit Reel Beacon.

A new beacon has been erected on the North end of Towartit Reef (Lat 19° 31’ 40” N, Long : 37° 19’ E) in place of the old one which was washed away. The beacon consists of a stone pyramid 21 feet high, painted white, on a concrete base. It is surmounted by a staff and triangle painted red ; total height of beacon above high water, 30 feet.
Remarkable Egyptian Bust.

The Louvre has recently acquired a lifesize bust, in chalk, primitively coloured, of the heretic king of the Eighteenth Dynasty, Akhonmalon, or Amenophis IV., one of the strangest figures in the long line of the Phara- ohs. The bust is a remarkably fine specimen of the art of the period, and is well preserved. Besides this,there are four sepulchral urns in blue porcelain from the tomb of Rameses II. Io these urns was found, besides funeral linen, certain organic matter, which is being chemi- cally examined.
Chapter of Motor Accidents

Last week was a record one for motor car accidents in Cairo. To start with : On Wed- nesday morning, at 11 o’clock, a Jewish girl of thirteen was ran over by a car mounted by M. Paul Conin Fastour ; the wheels went over her body without doing her any harm. The same evening a native was knocked down near the English Bridge, Ghezireh, but sustained no injuries. What is strange about this accident is that the owner, who is said to belong to the Khedivial family, disappeared while the driver had got down to pick up the native, and although the astonished chauffeur made a thorough search, his master had gone, and so he had to return, empty, to the garage.—From Dinard comoes the news of the spill of M. Achillopoulo, son of the late well known sports- man of Cairo. M. Achillopoulo was driving along at a dizzy speed, when something went wrong sod be and his chauffeur were shot out, the latter being rather seriously injured.
Al Fresco Dance.

The "Al Fresco” dance hold at Kasr el Nil on Tuesday last was quite the greatest success of its kind ever given in Cairo. As was anticipated, quite a large crowd assembled, and although the accommodation was spacious, the number of officers, members and their friends, amply, though comfortably, filled the court. The splendid band of the Royal In- niskilling Fusiliers was in attendance, and the music left nothing to be desired, dancing being started punctually at 9.30 p.m. and kept up well into the small hours of the morning. The dancing was quite of the best, tho dainty costumes of the ladies interspersed with the smart uniforms of officers and N. C. officers, and the neat, if sombre, evening dress, presented a perfect kaleidoscope of colour, charming to the eye. During the interval, coffee, ices, etc., were handed round and it is only fair to state that the coffee was pronounced to be the drink “par ex- cellence of the evening. All who attended this dance are looking eagerly for the next ; Sergeant Major Lamsden and his staff are to be congratulated on their untiring efforts to bring about such an unqualified success. The "Freezer," an entirely new dance, will, we hear, be introduced at the next function.
New Employment Registry.

The British Chamber of Commerce gives notice that it has commenced an employment register, which may be consulted by members requiring clerical or other assistance. Ap- plications will be received, free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in Egypt Address, Secretory, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria [Advt.]

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
H.H. EN ROUTE FOR VIENNA.
div.p: Kissingen, September 2.
The Khedive has left for Viena. (Reuter)
On the occasion of the Mohamedan Feast of Leitei Raghaib on the 24th ult., H.H. the Khedive sent the Sultan a message of felicita- tion, which his Imperial Majesty graciously acknowledged.

The Khedive is very fond of his palace at Tchiboukli on the Bosphorus. Recently his Highness ordered a tower to be added to the Palace, which will command a magnificent view. The construction was stopped before his Highness left Constantinople during his last visit, but the work has now been resumed.

div.head: THE SIRDAR
div.p: Major-General Sir Francis Wingate, who on Saturday week opened a bazaar in connection with the Parish Church at Dunbar, apologised for the absence of Mr.Haldaue, who was to have performed the ceremony, but who had been summoned by the King to Marienbad. He himself, he said, was merely a sojourner in Dunbar, a bird of passage who hibernated in the far-off valley of the Nile, and, when pos- sible, made periodic descents on to the health- giving shores of Dunbar there to reap a store of good, fresh air to enable him to do his duty to his King and country in a somewhat remote and distinctly warm corner of the globe. As a soldier be w[print error]s rightly debarred from touching on politics, but, in the absence of Mr. Haldane, he thought be might be allowed to quote a few of his words, which though intended for wider issues, nevertheless applied equally to the efforts to organise that bazzar and bring it to a successful issue. Mr. Haldane said : “Science is as essential to victory in the arts of war as in those of peace. Organisation is the key to success. Organisation depends on ideas, ideas give birth to ideals.” Mr. Haldane insisted on what he called the trained mind, and to acquire that he said, “Educate, edu- cate " lu[unsure word] Europe, continued Sir Francis, the truth of those words was as clear as daylight, and the workers in the more distant and less civilised parts of the globe daily realised their increasing truth,and were grateful to the theory of the necessity of science in the art of govern- ment and in the administration of public affairs. Especially were they grateful to Mr. Haldane, who had never failed to propound those principles with no small measure of success.

div.head: SIR ELWIN PALMER.
div.p: At Somerset House the estate in the United Kingdom of Sir Elwin Milford Palmer, K.C.B., K.C.M.G, Governor of the National Bank of Egypt, and formerly Financial Adviser to the Khedive, who died last January at Cairo, aged fifty four years, has been entered for probate at £9.607.

div.head: MILITARY NIGHT OPERATIONS.
div.p: Night operations will be carried out by the Cairo Garrison, on the night of Thursday next. The columns will be commanded as follows:—
No. 1 Column—Lieut. CoI. J. H. Gideon Commanding : 1st Battalion Lancashire Fusi- liers.
No. 2. Column—Lieut.-Col. C. J. Markham, Commanding: 1st Battalion K.R R Corps.
No. 3 Column—Major C. J.L. Davidson, D.S 0.. Commanding : 2nd Battalion Royal In- niskilling Fusiliers, less 4 Componies.
No. 4 Column—Brevet Lieut.-Col. H. M. Campbell, Commonding: “U" Battery, R.H.A., 6th Inniskilling Dragoons. Detachment, M M P.
The troops will probably not reach barracks before 7 am. the following morning.

div.head: THE THIRD COLDSTREAMS.
div.p: One of the questions which Mr. Haldane will place before the King is (the London correspondent of the “Manchester Guardian" learns) the disbandment of the 3rd Coldstream Guards. By being sent to Egypt this regiment was granted a reprieve, and there is a possi- bility that it may yet be saved to the army.

div.head: EGYPTIAN DELTA LIGHT RAILWAYS.
div.p: The committee of the London Stock Ex- change have ordered the following security to be quoted in the Official List: —
Egyptian Delta Light Railways. Ltd.- Further issue of 1 5 3 5 1/2 per cent, cumula tive preference shares of £10 each, fully paid, Nos. 85,541 to 104,078.

div.head: SAN STEFANO NEW THEATRE,
div.p: Tomorrow night there will be e special enter- tainmenr for the benefit of all the corps de ballet; the Hellenic Philharmonic Band playing in the intervals. Among other artistes Mme Mary Flenr and Mme Deparme, and Messrs. Stavil, Moper, and Zos-Zos will take part.
Nearly all the boxes have been booked.
INTSTRUMENTAL CONCERTS
Every Nights
On the Verandah of the
WINDSOR, HOTEL
Alexandria
FROM 6 TO 12 P.M.
5 O'clock Tea Served on Verandah

div.head: SULTAN’S ACCESSION FETES.
EGYITIANS AND THEIR PADISHAH
div.p: (From our Correspondent).

During the business hours of Saturday there was but little evidence to show that the Moslem world of Cairo were celebrating the anniversary of the Accession of Abdul Hamid II. to the Throne of Turkey. The Ministries and public offices remained open and business was carried on uninterruptedly among the natives. The Esbekieh Gardena, however, were occupied most of the day by women and children and there seemed to be more than usual of these in the neighbouring streets, and as one passed the gardens one could bear the doleful, discordant wailings of the zummareh and arghool, accompanied by the tuneless scratchings of the kemengeh and dull thuds from darabukkeh. A considerable number of the larger buildings and shops in the main streets flew the Ottoman and other flags and the Esbekieh Gardens were decorated in the customary style with tall poles wound with red and white bearing the star and crescent at their summits, and nu- merous lamps, while the several tents with their gorgeous satayer lent much pictures queness to the general scene, especially after dark, when every corner was brilliantly illu- minated.
In the morning a reception was held at the Gouvernorat by Mohamed Pasha Sidki and was attended by the ulema, Sheikhs, and all the Moslem notabilities of Cairo.

Towards five o’clock the main street of the Capital became more crowded, the noises from the Gardens grew loader and more continuous, schoolboys from the various ma- daris marched in state to the Gardens to the accompaniment of bands, and there was every in- dication of a great fantasia. The native popula- tion had realised that a fantasia had been prepared for them. But the question was sug- gested to me, “Had many of these people in the streets know the reason thereof ?“ In a spirit of curiosity I asked one or two of the passers by what was going on and in every instance I received the answer "Fantasia ala- shan el Effendina" but none could say with certainty who was the Effendina referred to— one indeed laid it was for the Khedive—or why this fantasia should be held in his honour, I refer, of course, to the uneducated classes for it is certain that those who have attended schools knew the reasons of the celebration. The fact, however, was impressed upon me that a considerable portion of Egypt's popula- tion is either altogether ignorant of even the existence of a Sultan or has very vague ideas as to who be is and what power he has.

After dark the railings round the Esbekieh Gardens were illuminated by lanterns set closely together end inside the gardens all of the many lamps were lighted and the scene was most brilliant From 9 to 11 p.m. the band of the Inniskilling Fusiliers played a selection of music, and there were, besides, several native bands, while the tents were crowded with those who wished to listen to the story-tellers or musicians or witness tight rope walkers, jugglers, end the like.

The Tahdrieh School, Saida Zenab, celebrat- ed the anniversary on Friday evening with a very successful entertainment which included a long and well varied programme. A con- siderable number of people were present be- sides the scholars, chief among whom were were Mohamed Arif Bey, representing Mukh- tar Pasha, and Ahmed Faik Pasha, represent log H. H. the Khedive, both of whom deliver- ed laudatory addresses.
The Regent’s Banquet.

The barquet which was given at Ras-el-Tin Palace by Boutros Paths Ghali, the acting Regent on Saturday evening on the occasion of the Sultan’s accession fete was attended by the Ministers, Mr. Findlay, Nouri Bey, Se cretory to Ghazi Mukhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, Lord E. Cecil, Mr. Brunyate, Mr. Dunlop, Mr. Gould, and the Consular Corps, the President and Judges of the Mixed Tribunals end of the native courts, Ismail Pasha Sabri, Ibrahim Pasha Serhank, Saba Pasha, the G.O.C., Army of Occu- pation, the high officials of the Municipality, the sub-Governor, the chief officials of the Maieh, etc. After the banquet was over the Regent paid a formal visit to the acting Imperial Ottoman Commissioner at Palace No. 3. There was a magnificent display of fireworks at Ras-el-Tin,

div.head: NEW CREDITS.
div.p: The Government has granted the following credits:-L.E. 20,000 for a steamship line between Kerma and Dongola; LE 800 for preliminary works for the bridges at Khartum; LB 100 for works at Bahr E! Arab; and LE- 265,000 for extensive works in the Soudan.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: Tin Moss liner Khephren arrived here yes- terday morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers and Malta, with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Messageries Maritimes S.S. Portugal left Marseilles on August 30th and is due here on the 4th inst.; she passed Messina Straits at noon on Saturday.
The Ellerman SS. Austrian railed from Malta on Saturday evening and is due here on Wednesday morning with passengers and a general cargo.
The Ellerman S.S. Belgravian sailed hence an Saturday evening for Liverpool with a general cargo including 1,985 bales of cotton.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
THE OSMANIEH.
div.p: On Thursday next the Khedivial Mail Line will give a “private view” of the “Osmanieh” end as no doubt many will be eager to avail themselves of the Company's invitation to visit this magnificent addition to its fleet, a brief de- scription of the steamer will be of interest The “Osmanieh” has been built at Wallsend on the Tyne by Messrs. Swan Hunter and Wigham Richardson. The new steamer is an important addition to the growing fleet of this Company, she having been specially constructed to meet the increasing demand for the first class ser- vice between Alexandria, Athens, and Constan- tinople, between which ports she will run and carry the mails. She is 380fr. in length by 45ft 3in. in breadth, her gross tonnage being 4,040 tons, and her two screw engines, which wore constructed by the Wallsend Engineering and Slipway Company, are tour-cranked triple expansion engines of 6,500 h.p. In addition to accommodating 144 first-class and 76 second-class passengers, she has an Imperial suite of cabins, especially intended for potentates, pashas, and millionaires, and, needless to say, these ere furnished in the most exquisite styles whilst there are spacious dining, drawing, writing, and smoking rooms, and also capacity for carrying 2,000 tons of cargo. The 'tween decks are arranged for the carriage of third-class passengers or troops.

The general impression derived from a visit to the ship is that of the extreme comfort of all her passenger arrangements. The pas- sages are very broad and there is an air of spaciousness in her accommodation which is often lacking in far bigger passenger steamers. The greatest credit is due to Mr. Parkinson, the general manager to the Com- pany, who is responsible for the design of the passenger arrangements. Nothing has been overlooked to render the vessel up-to- date in every respect end no finer steamer can be found plying between any Levantine ports. On the voyage out she gave every satisfaction and proved herself most seaworthy. Her trials in the North Sea also proved emi- nently satisfactory. On her speed trials she exceeded her guaranteed speed by half a knot, whilst in her final run from the Tyne to Southampton, her average speed was sixteen knots. On her voyage out she created a record for the all sea journey from England to Alexandria. Captain Gatteschi has been given the command and his place on the “Ismailia” will be filled by Captain Anderlich from the “Prince Abbas.”
By kind permission of Colonel Chapman and the officers of the Royal Dublin Fusiliers, the band of the Regiment will be in attendance for the private view on Thursday afternoon.
The general public will be admitted to view the vessel on Saturday and Sunday next on presentation of their visiting cards.

div.head: NEW ORIENTAL LINE.
div.p: The “National Zeitung,” of Berlin, comments sarcastically upon the report published in the London newspapers to the effect that the Bombay shippers and merchants were indignant at the news that the Hamburg-America Line intends to establish a regular and permanent service between the Persian Gulf, the Suez Canal, and India. The “National Zeitung” adds that much greater significance will attach to this enterprise as coon as the Bagdad Railway has been completed to its projected terminus on the Persian Gulf, for then direct communica- tion between the Mediterranean and Asia will be established independent of the Suez Canal.

div.head: LETTER TO THE EDITOR.
div.ab: We do not hold ourselves responsible for the opinions ex- pressed by our correspondents, but we wish, in a spirit of fair play to all. to permit-within certain necessary limits —free discussion.
div.p: PURIFICATION OF ALEXANDRIA.

To the Editor or the "Egtptian Gazette.” Sir,— Although so many people appear to be interested in the “Morality Crusade’’ now being carried on in Alexandria, not one of them appears to have struck the right note to prevent the ladies of the demi-monde from carrying on their profession. The care is a simple as possible. Do not allow them to land in Egypt. Not one of these ladies ere born in Egypt They are all Europeans, Germans, Italians, French, etc., Then why allow them to land here? They all come here for the express purpose of carrying on their profes- sion, and in the "season” they come on pur- pose to live on the “Tourist.” It would not be a difficult matter to pick out these “ladies" on the arrival of every steamer, and when the first lot or two were turned back, the news would soon spread, and no more would come.

I think this would be a much better way than allowing them to "land” and then hunt- ing them from “pillar to post," as is being done at present by the so-called “purity" brigade of which Mr. P. Rudolph appears to be one of the leaders, quite forgetting that these poor girls are “human beings” and were once as pure as the "hunters’" own mothers, and should have a little compassion shown them, if, for no other reason, than that they are "women."

It is nothing to the credit of Mr. P. Rudolph (who appears to be a caretaker or something, of some “home," kept up by public subscription) that he should go out of his way to hustle these poor girls around as he speaks of having done for a number of years. It would be better if he followed the precepts laid down in the "Christian Bible," “and did unto others as he would be done unto."—Yours, etc.,
J. P.
Cairo, September 1.

div.head: EGYPT AND SYRIA.
CEREAL EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: ( From our Correspondent. )
Beyrout, August 22.

Our intercourse with Egypt in regard to both Syrian exports of goods and the Egyptian exodus of summer visitors has been exception- ally lively this year. It is estimated that over 14,000 Egyptians are now scattered in different villages of the Lebanon. Oar Passport Department, realizing the profits that are likely to accrue both to the Government and the country at large from the visit and pro- longed sojourn of this more or less wealthy class of Egyptians, has been particularly courteous this year, and the large number of Egyptian visitors this season may be accounted for thereby. This is a matter of congratula- tion, the more so as certain regrettable inci- dents in the past have seriously indisposed the Egyptians against Syria, leading many to shun it persistently.
Exports to Egypt.

As regards our exports to Egypt, unusual quantities of beans and barley, and, to a certain extent, wheat, have been shipped from the Syrian coast, owing apparently to the failure of these crops in Egypt, or else to the diminished cultivation of these products, or perhaps to both factors. Indeed the demand has been so strong and sustained that it has perturbed very seriously the local trade. Our local market has been to excited by this extraordinary Egyptian demand that spot prices rose to s figure quite incompatible with the European and British markets, which by reason of their absorbing the bulk of these exports have always been the determining factor in the fluctuations of our local markets. At one time it was thought that this demand would soon be satisfied, and a normal condition of things would be resumed. But contrary to the predictions of experienced authorities the demand persisted longer then it had been thought, with the result that the reaction still continues. The big merchants, who export annually thousands of tons of grain to the Continent and the United Kingdom, are having their hands tied, and grain transactions with the above-mentioned countries are being serious- ly hampered. The inefficiency of the railway transport is crowning their evils. To give an idea of the abnormal nature of this Egyptian demand I may mention as an instance, the two facts that 2,500 tons of Gaza barley have arrived and been sold in Egypt in one single week, when this figure almost represented, formerly, the exports of a whole campaign from Gaza to Egypt, and that by one Messageries steamer 500 tons of grain were shipped from Beyrout to Alexandria. A statistical list, showing the total of exports of grain from the Syrian coast to Egypt during this campaign, will no doubt contain most startling figures. Some people think that this unusually strong Egyptian demand has not been solely deter- mined by the law of supply and demand, but rather by the spirit of speculation that[smudge] has permeated so deeply into the soul of Egyptians.

div.head: EGYPT AND UGANDA.
div.p: "The African World" says: - The movement set on foot in Egypt to increase the cultivable land area by means of the construction of a number of huge storage reservoirs, apart from its importance from the commercial side, is calculated to react bene- ficially on the development of Uganda and British East Africa generally. With a view to carrying out the above project, the Egyptian Government has decided to make a hydrogra- phic survey of the whole of the banks of the Nile right up to Lake Victoria, and also of the countries stretching between that lake and the East Coast of Africa. A mission has been nominated, at the head of which is Captain Lyons, Director General of the Surveys Depart- ment, to oarry out the first portion of these labours. The data collected in districts so little known will be of the first importance to hydrographic questions related to Uganda itself and British East Africa. In particular the debateable questions of the relations of the several great lakes to the Nile will be settled, also some light thrown on the river systems of the British protectorate, which should be of value in connection with such schemes s=as, say, the utilising of the Ripon Falls for the gene- ration of electricity and other similar under- takings.

div.head: GERMANY AND EGYPT.
div.p: According to the 'Sohlesische Zeitung" (Berlin, Aug. 16) the German Foreign Office will be very remiss if it does not take the opportunity when Lord Cromer’s proposals for the reform of the judicial system in Egypt come up for discussion to compel the British Government to grant to Germany an Egyptian "open door" in perpetuity in exchange for Germany's consent to the abolition of the Capi- tulations. Lord Cremer’s proposed reforms are regarded in Berlin as a preparatory step to the annexation of Egypt by England, and Germany is urged by the "Schlesischne Zeitung" and a number of other journals to utilise the situa- tion to extract compensation for forgoing all right to interfere with the British designs. The two concessions Germany would like are an uninterrupted and free market in Egypt and a terminus on the Persian Gulf for the Baghdad Railway. If she can manage a "deal" on these lines German diplomacy would be triumphant. While counselling reserve in treating Egyp- tian questions, the "Berliner Neueste Nach- richten" (Aug 16) observes that since Bis- marck's time the relations of Turkey to Egypt have become for Germany a matter of greater importance. Germany's interests are increasing in the Near Best, and it has become one of the leading points of German policy in the Orient that the sovereignly of the Sultan shall not be impugned.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Boutros Pasha Ghali, Minister for Foreign Affairs, left San Stefano this morning for Cairo, whence he will proceed this evening to Port Said to catch a steamer for Merseilles.
Lord Cromer is now on a visit to Mr. Thomas Baring, at Strathmore Lodge, Caith- ness.
The King has been pleased to approve off the appointment of Charles Robert Tyser, Esq , (Puisne Judge), to be Chief Jastice of the Supreme Court of Cyprus.
The widow of the late Ibrahim Pasha Cherif, who is an Italian lady, has taken up her resi- dence at the Carlton House.
Mirza Ali Asghar Khan, the Persian Diplo- matic Agent in Cairo, who has arrived in Vienna, is the brother of the Persian Ambas- sador at Stamboul, the Apostle of Peace.

A marriage has been arranged and will take place at the end of October between Constance Manners Sutton, eldest daughter of Colonel Chichester, late of the 5th Lancers, of West Mains Sunnioghill, and Ottiwell Frank Water field, the Oaklands, Hartford, Cheshire, eldest surviving son of the late 0. C. Waterfield, Nackington, Nr Canterbury.
Leave of absenoe, on private affairs, has been granted to Mr. J. Quibell, Chief Inspector of Antiquities, and Mahmoud Effendi Sami, assistant engineer of Zifta circle.

M. Gaillordot, French Vice-Consul at Haifa, has been promoted Consul of the second-class, a promotion which has been well merited by thirty years' service in the Orient. M. Gaillor- dot was appointed on June 20, 1876, to the Consulate at Alexandria, and since then has risen to be successively dragoman of the French Diplomatic Agency at Cairo, dragoman-chan- cellor at Beyrout, and Vice-Consul at Haifa.
Nungovich Bay and Mr. Alfred Campos arrived at Alexandria from Europe to-day.

A telegram from Naples reports the death from heart failure of Mr. Kimon Accavalos, head of the Legal Department of the Credit Foncier Egyptian. Mr. Accavalos had only left Egypt quite recently on two months' leave.
Major A. S. Cave, 2nd Battalion, Royal Berkshire Regiment; has been granted leave of absence in extension from 10th October to 30th November.
Lieut. 0. C. Hewitt, 2nd Battalion Royal luniskilling Fusiliers, has been granted leave of absence, on private affairs, from to-day until the 13th inst.
The Ministry of the Interior has given an authorisation to Mr. Spiridion Cephalonitia to pursue the trade of a chemist in Egypt

div.head: EDEN PALACE HOTEL
div.p: Cairo
Noted for its excellent cuisine.
Electric Light, lift.
Special terms for officers o the Army of Occupation and Government Officials.
